content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 1999". The Congress finds that asthma affects millions of Americans, with a significant impact on children. Allergies, including allergic asthma, also affect a large portion of the population. Asthma is a common respiratory disease in children, leading to school absenteeism and preventable hospitalizations. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly, especially among preschool children. Women and low-income families are more likely to be affected by asthma. In families with annual incomes below $10,000, 79.2 out of 1,000 individuals under 45 have asthma, compared to 53.6 out of 1,000 in families earning $20,000 to $35,000. In 1997, over 5,000 Americans died from asthma attacks. African Americans had an average of 38.5 deaths per million individuals from asthma, while Caucasians had 15.1 deaths per million. Asthma costs the US over $12 billion annually, with rising prevalence leading to higher future costs. African Americans are five times more likely than other groups to seek asthma care in emergency rooms. The asthma death rate is significantly higher among African American children and adults. Exercise can improve the well-being of children with asthma, helping them manage the condition and develop lifelong habits of physical activity. Grants for asthma-related activities in low-income communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants for projects in low-income communities focusing on screenings, education, and workshops for asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems. The screenings and referrals will be conducted to ensure early detection and appropriate care for individuals in these communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services provides comprehensive screenings and referrals for asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems in various settings including medical facilities and nontraditional locations like schools, community centers, and government offices. Information and education on these conditions are also ensured by the Secretary. The Secretary of Health and Human Services provides information and education on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems in various settings. This includes providing information in appropriate language and cultural context, educating on symptoms, prevention, monitoring, and management of these conditions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services provides information and education on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems in traditional and nontraditional settings. Evaluations of projects include determining the number of children who received screenings and referrals. The projects aim to assess their impact on managing asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues in individuals. Grants require involvement of a local community-based organization in project implementation. The organization will have a substantial role in project implementation. The Secretary may grant funds if the application meets necessary requirements. $8,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for subsequent years. SEC. 4. NATIONAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN TO PROVIDE ASTHMA-RELATED INFORMATION. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign to provide information on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems, with a focus on children. The campaign must include information on prevention and management of these conditions and highlight available community programs. Tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services under SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services under SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. For taxpayers providing qualified services, the donation credit is 10 percent of the costs incurred in providing these services in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties. The provision allows a tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties where at least 75 percent of occupants have incomes below 200 percent of the poverty line. The services must be part of a good faith effort and verified as prescribed by the Secretary. Pest control and climate control services include eliminating pests and improving ventilation and temperature control. The amendment adds a new paragraph to the tax code allowing a donation credit for pest control and climate control services provided by taxpayers in the specified business. Additionally, it prohibits the carryback of the credit before January 1, 2000. The tax code amendment allows a donation credit for pest control and climate control services provided by taxpayers in specified businesses. Unused business credit cannot be carried back before January 1, 2000. The tax code amendment allows a donation credit for pest control and climate control services. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. Additionally, there is research being conducted on the relationship between air pollutants and asthma-related problems. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Clinical research will prioritize individuals for clinical evaluations. Residents of communities with family incomes at or below 200 percent of the poverty line are the focus of this paragraph. SEC. 7. COORDINATION OF FEDERAL ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS ASTHMA-RELATED HEALTH CARE NEEDS. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will work with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee to identify federal asthma programs, develop a federal response plan, and improve coordination of asthma-related activities. The Department of Housing and Urban Development will have a representative on the committee. The National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee will receive $5,000,000 from the National Institutes of Health for fiscal years 2000 through 2004 to carry out specified tasks. SEC. 8. COMPILATION OF DATA BY CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, conducts local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management. This includes telephone surveys and health care facility surveillance. They also compile and publish data on the prevalence of children with asthma in each state and the childhood mortality rate associated with asthma nationally and in each state.
